content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. Amendments are made to outpatient care provisions, including extending care for disabilities before December 31, 1994. The eligibility for inpatient care for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. Amendments are made to outpatient care provisions, including extending care for disabilities before December 31, 1994. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) shall take effect as of August 2, 1990. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will reimburse veterans for care related to toxic substance exposure during the Persian Gulf War. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) will be effective as of August 2, 1990. The extension of certain health care and other authorities includes eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation, eligibility for sexual trauma counseling, and the authority to maintain a regional office in the Philippines. Amendments extend deadlines for eligibility criteria. Section 315(b) of title 38, United States Code, amended to change deadline to December 31, 1994. Section 3692(c) amended to change deadline to December 31, 1994 for Advisory Committee on Education. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of amending section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. The definition of "health-care resource" is expanded to include various services and support. Sharing of health-care resources is further detailed in section 8153(a) of the title. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements for the sharing of specialized medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other institutions, as well as health-care resources between Department facilities and State home facilities. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements for sharing medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other institutions to avoid duplication or underutilization of resources justified for veterans' care.
